resources.string:
Kohli has been deemed one of the most commercially viable athletes, with estimated earnings of ₹634 crore (US$79 million) in the year 2022.

Early life
Virat Kohli was born on 5 November 1988 in Delhi into a Punjabi Hindu family. His father, Prem Kohli, worked as a criminal lawyer, and his mother, Saroj Kohli, served as a housewife. He has an older brother, Vikas, and an older sister, Bhawna.[8] Kohli's formative years were spent in Uttam Nagar. He commenced his early education at Vishal Bharti Public School.[9] According to his family, Kohli exhibited an early affinity for cricket as a mere three-year-old. He would pick up a cricket bat, display natural skill, and request his father to bowl to him.[10]

In 1998, the West Delhi Cricket Academy (WCDA) was created. On 30 May of that year, Prem Kohli, who'd espoused his younger son's fervour for cricket, assisted nine-year-old Kohli's aspirations and arranged for him to meet Rajkumar Sharma, who initially perceived him to be just another enthusiastic and determined young boy. However, two weeks later, Sharma was impressed by Kohli's accuracy and power in throwing.[11] Upon the suggestion of their neighbours, Kohli's father considered enrolling his son in a professional cricket academy, as they believed that his cricketing abilities merited more than just playing in gully cricket.[12] Despite his abilities, he faced the setback of being unable to secure a place in the under-14 Delhi team, not due to a lack of merit but due to extraneous factors. Prem Kohli received offers to relocate his son to influential clubs, which would have ensured his selection, but he declined the proposals, as he was determined that Kohli should earn his recognition based on his own merit and overcome the system of nepotism and deceit prevalent in the Delhi and District Cricket Association (DDCA). Kohli persisted and eventually found his way into the under-15 Delhi team.[13]

Virat Kohli ( born 5 November 1988)is an Indian international cricketer and the former captain of the Indian national cricket team. He is a right-handed batsman and an occasional medium-fast bowler.
He currently represents Royal Challengers Bangalore in the IPL and Delhi in domestic cricket.
Kohli is widely regarded as one of the greatest batsmen in the history of cricket and the best of the 21st century.
He holds the record as the highest run-scorer in T20I and IPL, ranks third in ODI, and stands as the fourth-highest in international cricket.[4] He also holds the record for scoring the most centuries in ODI cricket and stands second in the list of most international centuries scored.
Kohli was a member of the Indian team that won the 2011 Cricket World Cup, 2013 ICC Champions Trophy, and captained India to win the ICC Test mace three consecutive times in 2017, 2018, and 2019.[5]

In 2013, Kohli was ranked number one in the ICC rankings for ODI batsmen. In 2015, he achieved the summit of T20I rankings.[6] In 2018, he was ranked top Test batsman, making him the only Indian cricketer to hold the number one spot in all three formats of the game. He is the first player to score 20,000 runs in a decade. In 2020, the International Cricket Council named him the male cricketer of the decade.[7]

He has received many accolades for his performances in cricket.
He won the ICC ODI Player of the Year award four times in 2012, 2017, 2018, and 2023. He also won the Sir Garfield Sobers Trophy, given to the ICC Cricketer of the Year, on two occasions, in 2017 and 2018 respectively. In 2018, he became the first player to win both ICC ODI and Test Player of the Year awards in the same year.

Also, he was named the Wisden Leading Cricketer in the World for three consecutive years, from 2016 to 2018. At the national level, Kohli was honoured with the Arjuna Award in 2013, the Padma Shri in 2017, and India's highest sporting honour, the Khel Ratna award, in 2018.

In 2018, Time magazine included him on its list of the 100 most influential people in the world.

Once upon a time, in a beautiful pond, there lived three fish—one was very clever, the second one was wise, and the third was carefree. They spent their days swimming and enjoying life, but little did they know, danger was about to strike. One day, two fishermen passed by the pond and saw the fish. Excited by their discovery, they decided to return the next day to catch them. The clever fish overheard the fishermens plan. Without wasting time, it quickly swam to its friends and warned them of the danger. The wise fish, understanding the severity of the situation, said, We must leave the pond immediately and find another safe place before the fishermen return.

The clever fish agreed and quickly swam away to a nearby river, finding safety before the fishermen arrived. But the carefree fish, who loved the pond and didn’t want to leave, laughed and said, Oh, I’ve been here my whole life! I’ll be fine. The fishermen won\'t catch me. The next day, the fishermen came as planned. They cast their nets into the pond, and while the wise and clever fish were safe in their new home, the carefree fish was caught in the net. The story reminds us that being clever and wise can help us avoid danger, while ignoring warnings may lead to trouble.

once_upon_a_time_in_a_beautiful_pond_there_lived_three_fish_one_was_very_clever_the_second_one_was_wise_and_the_third_was_carefree_they_spent_their_days_swimming_and_enjoying_life_but_little_did_they_know_danger_was_about_to_strike_one_day_two_fishermen_passed_by_the_pond_and_saw_the_fish_excited_by_their_discovery_they_decided_to_return_the_next_day_to_catch_them_the_clever_fish_overheard_the_fishermens_plan_without_wasting_time_it_quickly_swam_to_its_friends_and_warned_them_of_the_danger_the_wise_fish_understanding_the_severity_of_the_situation_said_we_must_leave_the_pond_immediately_and_find_another_safe_place_before_the_fishermen_return The moral of the “The Clever Fish” story is “one must be really-really clever to save their life from challenging moments.”

The story of Two Frogs is about two frogs that fall into a deep pit while traveling with their group through a forest. The other frogs, seeing the depth of the pit, discourage them from trying to escape, assuming they are doomed. Despite the negative comments, one frog persists in trying to jump out, while the other eventually gives up and tragically falls to its death.

The moral of the story is that we should be resilient in pursuing our goals and not let negative comments deter us. The deaf frog, unable to hear the discouragement, interprets the other frogs\' shouts as encouragement and perseveres until it successfully escapes the pit. This teaches children the importance of ignoring negativity, staying focused on their aspirations, and using criticism as motivation to achieve success.

The story follows a poor woodcutter named Ram, who lived on the outskirts of a village and earned his livelihood by cutting wood and selling it to a merchant. One day, while working near a river, his axe accidentally fell into the water. Distraught as his axe was his only means of income, Ram prayed for help. Moved by his sincerity, God appeared before him and offered to help. God first retrieved a silver axe from the river and asked if it belonged to Ram. Though tempted, Ram refused, saying it wasn’t his. Next, God pulled out a golden axe, but again, Ram honestly said that it wasn’t his axe. Finally, God retrieved Ram’s iron axe, and Ram gratefully accepted it. Impressed by Ram\'s honesty and integrity, God rewarded him by giving him the silver and golden axes along with his own. Ram accepted them with a grateful heart and continued to live an honest, contented life, no longer poor.

Moral of the Story: The story teaches that honesty is always the best policy. Ram, despite his difficult situation, remained truthful and was rewarded for his integrity. The story encourages children to be honest in all situations, showing that honesty is valued and leads to positive outcomes. This moral can be applied in real life by encouraging children to be truthful and kind, even when faced with challenges. Honesty helps build trust, and integrity is rewarded in the long run.

Once upon a time, there was a clever rooster who lived in a farmyard. One day, while wandering in the forest, he encountered a hungry fox. The fox, known for being sly, sweet-talked the rooster, saying, Dear Rooster, I have heard about your wonderful voice. Would you sing for me? The rooster, sensing the fox\'s cunning intentions, decided to outsmart him. Pretending to agree, the rooster said, Of course, I’ll sing for you, but first, you must close your eyes and bow your head in respect. The fox, eager to pounce on the rooster, did as he was told, closing his eyes and lowering his head. Seizing the opportunity, the rooster quickly flew up to a high tree branch, safely out of the fox’s reach. Realizing he had been tricked, the fox tried to convince the rooster to come down, but the rooster, now aware of the fox\'s deceit, refused to listen. He knew he had outwitted the fox, so he stayed safely perched on the branch, watching as the fox slinked away in defeat.

Moral of the Story: The story teaches that clever thinking can help us overcome dangerous situations, even when facing deceitful or cunning opponents. The rooster\'s quick wit saved him from being captured by the fox, showing that intelligence and presence of mind are often more valuable than physical strength. This moral can be applied in real life by encouraging children to think carefully and use their intellect to navigate tricky situations, rather than rushing into danger or trusting deceitful individuals.
